org.threadly.litesockets

Class SocketExecuterBase

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.threadly.concurrent.AbstractService
      • org.threadly.litesockets.SocketExecuterBase
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    NoThreadSocketExecuter, ThreadedSocketExecuter

    public abstract class SocketExecuterBase
extends org.threadly.concurrent.AbstractService

    • Constructor Detail

      • SocketExecuterBase

        public SocketExecuterBase()

    • Method Detail

      • addClient

        public abstract void addClient(Client client)
        Add a client object to the SocketExecuter. This will allow the client to read and write data to its socket. All SocketExecuters dont have to implement this (They can just throw instead), but if they dont Client objects can not be used by the SocketExecuter.
        Parameters:
        client - the client you are adding.

      • removeClient

        public abstract void removeClient(Client client)
        Remove a client object that has been added to the SocketExecuter. Once this is done the client will no longer be able to read/write to the socket. If a write buffer for the client exists it might not be completely flushed out yet. All reads should be at least queued for an action. All SocketExecuters dont have to implement this (They can just throw instead), but if they dont Client objects can not be used by the SocketExecuter.
        Parameters:
        client - the client object to remove from the SocketExecuter

      • addServer

        public abstract void addServer(Server server)
        This is used to add a Server object to a SocketExecuter. Once its added the Server object can begin accepting and processing new connections to it. All SocketExecuters dont have to implement this (They can just throw instead), but if they dont Server objects can not be used by the SocketExecuter.
        Parameters:
        server - adds a server to the SocketExecuter.

      • removeServer

        public abstract void removeServer(Server server)
        This is used to remove Server objects from a SocketExecuter. Once a server is removed it will no longer process new connections. It is important to note removing a server does not close any listen ports, you must .close() on the server to do that. All SocketExecuters dont have to implement this (They can just throw instead), but if they dont Server objects can not be used by the SocketExecuter.
        Parameters:
        server - removes a Server from the SocketExecuter

      • verifyReadThread

        protected abstract boolean verifyReadThread()
        This is used to figure out if the current used thread is the SocketExecuters ReadThread. This is used by clients to Enforce certain threads to do certain public tasks.
        Returns:
        a boolean to tell you if the current thread is the readThread for this executer.

      • flagNewWrite

        protected abstract void flagNewWrite(Client client)
        Flags a clients as having a newWrite pending. This will add it to the WriteThread and check it to see if it can write. This should only be called if the client did not currently have a pending write.
        Parameters:
        client - the Client object to flag for new write.

      • flagNewRead

        protected abstract void flagNewRead(Client client)
        This will add the client to the ReadThread. This can be called by the client once it can Read again. Basically if we have ever read enough to fill the clients Read Buffer and removed it from the ReadThread Thread this has to be called to add it back.
        Parameters:
        client - the Client object to flag for new Read.

      • getClientCount

        public abstract int getClientCount()
        Get the count of clients in this SocketExecuter.
        Returns:
        the number of clients.

      • getServerCount

        public abstract int getServerCount()
        Get the count of servers from the SocketExecuter.
        Returns:
        the number of Servers.

      • getThreadScheduler

        public abstract org.threadly.concurrent.SchedulerServiceInterface getThreadScheduler()
        This returns the current threadScheduler for this SocketExecuter. Every SocketExecuter must have a threadScheduler for it to executer client/server operations on.
        Returns:
        returns the threadScheduler the SocketExecuter is using.
